item.title: Quack/Play-More tech demo v0.01 (Video)
item.description: A video demonstration of the tech behind my upcoming game code named #MRK. A look more at the fancy Live Coding features built in to the engine. Everything works so well, it can be used for very rapid iterative development. The program never stops, all asset and code files are automatically reloaded, and if used correctly game state will stay the same across reloads. I‚Äôm hoping to do more videos as I introduce more general features, as well as when I have things to show in #MRK.

item.title: Conversation: Business and Fear
item.description: From Monday, Gianfranco (whom I abbreviate as GB) was concerned that some of the guys might have been fear-mongering after a recent set of very sad sad videos. That catapulted me in to a rant about‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ yeah, it‚Äôs actually that way. Indie truths a-plenty. The first begins on the subject of ‚Äúbig games are extremely risky‚Äù, despite doing one myself right now. I had some upload issues with the prior video, which lead me to watching my video a few more times, and expanding on the subject of indies and failures.

item.title: Introducing: The Indie Indie Conversation
item.description: Hello there! I figured now was a good time to talk about a project I‚Äôve been involved with for the past couple months now. Something we like to call, the Indie Indie Conversation. The conversation is a YouTube channel shared amongst a group of indie game developers where we talk about what we do, the challenges, and the lifestyle of creating games independently for a living. I‚Äôve personally failed many attempts at starting a regular video log here on my blog, and in retrospect that may have been the uncomfortable feeling of ‚Äútalking to a wall‚Äù.

item.title: Automobiles, Interviews, all Smiles
item.description: To say 2010 has been a busy year would be an understatement. While we were all waiting for Apple to confirm the existence of the iPad, I was busy tweaking, improving, and porting my game Smiles to a bunch of new platforms. The most significant port by far was to Netbook PCs for Intel‚Äôs AppUp Center, a brand new App Store coming soon to Netbooks everywhere. To say Intel and AppUp have been good to me, that would be another understatement.

item.title: Physics in Smiles
item.description: At first glance you wouldn‚Äôt think a matching game like Smiles would feature physics, but it does. In several places actually. The most obvious example is the particle effects. Particles were used when ice and rocks break, and also for the tile clearing effect. The tile would be erased instantly from the board, and a particle would be created in it‚Äôs place. The particle would zoom in, slow down, then zoom out with a twist.

item.title: Retrospective?
item.description: Yeah, sorry. I wanted to do detailed commentary of The Spider stuffs, the in between stuff, and get in to the new PuffBOMB stuff, but it looks like it didn‚Äôt happen. I wrote an outline and drafted a couple parts, but I wasn‚Äôt happy with the results. ‚ÄúNew PuffBOMB‚Äù has been down to just me since October. The artist finished his work, which turned out great. Richard got a job, and has been unavailable to help since.

item.title: The “New” Project, Part 1
item.description: Before starting work on ‚ÄúThe Spider‚Äù, I was building the engine for the ‚Äúnew PuffBOMB‚Äù. The concept behind the engine, 2D characters and physics, 3D backgrounds styled to look 2D, HD ready. Pretty standard stuff. The concept behind ‚ÄúThe Spider‚Äù is, unlike a normal platformer where you stand on the ground, this one you wouldn‚Äôt. Instead you would hang from and move along ceilings. The best idea I had at the time for pulling it off was something I nicknamed ‚Äúdouble ropes‚Äù, one to support, and one for action.
